In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area 
(BIMP-EAGA)1 recognizes the importance of trade facilitation in achieving its goals to increase 
trade and tourism and strengthen the economic integration of the growth area. BIMP-EAGA 
countries have committed to aligning their trade-facilitation programs with similar programs 
under the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and to serving as a testing ground 
for  fast-tracked  implementation.  BIMP-EAGA  leaders’  endorsement  of  priority  transport 
connectivity projects at their sixth summit in Cha-am, Thailand, in October 2009 underpinned 
the need for related policy and regulatory measures on trade facilitation. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported BIMP-EAGA since its establishment 
in 1994.2 It was appointed by BIMP-EAGA leaders as a regional development advisor in 2001. 
In 2007, ADB approved a regional technical assistance3 to strengthen the role of the BIMP-
EAGA Customs, Immigration, Quarantine, and Security Task Force (CIQS TF)4 as a platform for 
developing and implementing trade security and facilitation programs. The TA assisted the 
CIQS TF in formulating the Memorandum of Understanding for the Simplification, Streamlining, 
and Harmonization of Customs, Immigration, Quarantine, and Security Procedures (MOU), and 
in  preparing  standard  operating  procedures  (SOPs)  to  implement  the  MOU.  The  MOU  is 
expected to be signed in 2010. BIMP-EAGA countries requested at various forums held in 2009 
ADB  follow-on  TA  to  implement  the  MOU  and  the  SOPs  and  concurred  with  the  impact, 
outcomes, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference  for  the  proposed  regional  policy  and  advisory  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A review of the customs, immigration, quarantine, and security (CIQS) environment in 
BIMP-EAGA, conducted under the TA for Support for Customs, Immigration, Quarantine, and 
Security  Harmonization  in  Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN 
Growth Area, highlighted differences in CIQS capacity at priority entry points6 arising from 
member  countries’  varying  modes  of  and  progress  toward  compliance  with  international 
standards and conventions, as well as the wide disparity between developments achieved at the 
national  level  and  current  practices  at  the  priority  entry  points.  Performance  gaps  revolve 
around nonphysical barriers to the efficient movement of goods and people in the form of

Mindanao and Palawan in the Philippines. By making any designation of or reference to a particular territory or 
geographic area in this document, ADB does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of 
any territory or area. 
2  Since 1994, ADB has provided $13.22 million in technical assistance in support of BIMP-EAGA.

Harmonization in the Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area. Manila TA 
6408-REG for $600,000, approved on 20 August 2007. 
4  The CIQS TF is composed of senior officials from the national CIQS agencies of member countries. It serves as 
the institutional mechanism for coordination and information exchange on CIQS initiatives in BIMP-EAGA.  
5  The  TA  first  appeared  in  the  business  opportunities  section  of  ADB’s  website  on  04  January  2010 
(http://www.adb.org/projects/project.asp?id=41348). 
6  There are eight priority entry points: Muara port in Brunei Darussalam, Bitung port and Entikong border crossing in 
Indonesia, Labuan and Sandakan ports and Tebedu border crossing in Malaysia, and General Santos and 
Zamboanga ports in the Philippines. The CIQS TF designated them as pilot areas for CIQS initiatives to support 
cross-border trade and the movement of people.

2   
complex  procedures  and  numerous  documentation  requirements.  Clearing  procedures  and 
formalities are labor intensive and time consuming, as transactions are mostly paper based.  
 
5.  Need to streamline and standardize CIQS processes. The CIQS mapping exercise in 
BIMP-EAGA showed that as many as 15 documents are required for the clearance of incoming 
vessels  at  seaports,  which  must  be  submitted  to  at  least  seven  agencies.  Most  of  these 
documents are submitted to two or more agencies, thereby requiring at least 30 submissions 
per entry. Moreover, about eight documents are separately submitted to customs and other 
regulatory agencies for processing import clearance. This voluminous documentation illustrates 
the need for simplification and streamlining with a view to reducing the number of documentary 
requirements, enhancing data and information sharing among agencies, and exploring practical 
options to enable single submission and synchronized processing. The quantitative impacts of 
these constraints, though significant, are difficult to measure as trade transactions across BIMP-
EAGA are carried out by small and informal traders. Average clearance times exceed 1 day at 
most ports, while land border clearance takes more than 3 hours. Given the low volume of trade 
transactions in these entry points, average clearance times are considered high. The standard 
deviations are also high, suggesting unpredictability in the clearance process that makes it 
difficult for traders to plan business and ensure the timely delivery of goods. In addition, the 
movement of people across BIMP-EAGA needs facilitation to support both trade and tourism. 
Although  EAGA  nationals  enjoy  visa-exempt  entry  for  a  limited  stay  following  an  ASEAN 
arrangement, CIQS facilitation measures are needed for such frequent travelers as cross-border 
commuting workers, crews of border-crossing vessels such as fishers, operators of cross-border 
vehicles, and visiting third-country nationals. Foreign visitors face difficulty traveling across 
BIMP  countries  by  sea  or  land  because  of  inadequate  visa-on-arrival  facilities  at  major 
checkpoints, as well as lengthy, complicated procedures for bringing their personal effects 
through customs and quarantine. 
 
6.  Lack  of  capacity  to  implement  international  standards  and  best  practices. 
Diagnostic studies carried out under the TA for Support for Customs, Immigration, Quarantine, 
and  Security  Harmonization  in  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East 
ASEAN Growth Area showed that efforts to standardize CIQS systems at local entry points 
should  be  accompanied  by  corresponding  enhancement  of  local  CIQS  officials’  skills  and 
behavior. At most BIMP-EAGA entry points, improvements initiated by member countries are 
inefficiently enforced for lack of local officials’ understanding of updated international standards 
and skills required to implement trade-facilitation reforms. The lack of efficient communication 
among local CIQS agencies and across entry points hinders the exchange of information. This 
is an important element of border control, risk assessment, and trade facilitation reforms called 
for in the MOU.  
 
7.  Need  to  establish  and/or  strengthen  coordination  mechanisms  for  trade 
facilitation.  Institutional  mechanisms  need  to  be  strengthened  to  ensure  the  effective 
implementation of initiatives to facilitate trade. The MOU provides for strengthening the CIQS TF 
and establishing national and local CIQS-coordinating bodies to ensure the regular exchange of 
information  and  provide  appropriate  support  mechanisms.  The  CIQS  TF  should,  with  the 
support of its secretariat, continue to provide strategic direction subregionally, while in-country 
institutional structures facilitate vertical and horizontal coordination and collaboration. The local 
CIQS coordinating bodies should provide the venue at the port level for local agencies, in 
consultation with the private sector and local government representatives, to address issues 
that require integrated responses from multiple agencies. These include synchronizing working 
hours, rationalizing controls, conducting joint inspections, and other activities that involve mutual 
assistance and cooperation among border agencies.  Strengthening the capacity of local CIQS-

3
coordinating bodies is clearly an operational imperative to ensure the effective implementation 
of the MOU. 
 
8.  Opportunity  to  strengthen  public–private  partnership  for  trade  facilitation. The 
BIMP-EAGA CIQS TF and the BIMP-EAGA heads of customs welcome the participation of the 
private sector, through the BIMP-EAGA Business Council (BEBC), at their annual meetings. 
The  BEBC  regularly  addresses  trade  facilitation  issues  arising  in  consultations  with  local 
business  communities  in  BIMP-EAGA.  This  form  of  public–private  partnership  should  be 
continued and further expanded to include local consultative platforms at which the private 
sector can recommend measures to address their concerns in cross-border trade. 
 
9.  Need to address poor private sector compliance. At the recent dialogue conducted 
during the third meeting of the BIMP-EAGA heads of customs in September 2009, the BEBC 
acknowledged that the private sector’s lack of awareness on CIQS rules, regulations, and 
procedures (RRPs) and poor access to information, as well as the lack of transparency and 
predictability of transactions and inadequate trade infrastructure at EAGA borders, are major 
factors limiting compliance and the volume of trade. Most traders in BIMP-EAGA are small and 
micro-entrepreneurs unfamiliar with conventional trading methods, and the resulting prevalence 
of  informal  trade  transactions  leaves  traders  vulnerable  to  rent-seeking.  Local  businesses’ 
awareness  of  CIQS  RRPs  needs  to  be  enhanced  to  help  them  improve  their  business 
processes to meet the requirements of the international supply chain.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the TA is expected to be increased trade and tourism in BIMP-EAGA. The 
envisioned outcome of the TA is faster movement of goods and people at the eight priority entry 
points (footnote 6). This is expected to have spillover effects enhancing the efficiency of other 
entry  points  and  the  utilization  of  transport  infrastructure  and  links  connecting  subregional 
markets. The TA will complement progress in transport connectivity in BIMP-EAGA and help 
identify opportunities for public and private investments in trade-related infrastructure. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will adopt a phased approach to implementing reforms, taking into consideration 
the basic needs and resources available at each priority entry point. It will implement measures 
that  can  produce  early  gains  for  trade.  Recognizing  the  notable  disparity  in  performance 
between EAGA entry points and national capital ports, reforms and capacity building that narrow 
this development gap will be prioritized. This will be complemented with the strengthening of 
institutional mechanisms and public–private partnership and the adoption of monitoring and 
reporting mechanisms to track progress. The benefits from initial demonstrational results would 
help create incentives and mobilize further support to move forward in subsequent stages when 
countries review, update and reform their SOPs. The TA is expected to deliver two major 
outputs—improved CIQS systems at priority entry points and better private sector compliance—
through the following.  
 
1.  Improved CIQS Systems at Priority Entry Points 
 
12.  Validation of SOPs and rationalization of CIQS RRPs. The CIQS TF agreed that 
countries will formulate SOPs to implement the MOU in the priority entry points. As of April 2010,

4   
SOPs of three entry points, namely Muara Port (Brunei Darussalam), Sandakan Port (Malaysia) 
and General Santos (the Philippines), have been substantially completed, while those of other 
priority entry points are still subject to further refinement. The TA will support CIQS TF meetings 
to validate and review local SOPs and to discuss and endorse rationalized CIQS RRPs for each 
entry  point.  The  rationalization  of  CIQS  RRPs  will  simplify  clearance  procedures  and 
requirements to facilitate legitimate trade in accordance with international standards without 
undermining  countries'  capacity  to  regulate  cross-border  activities.  For  this  reason,  the 
development of new working systems and procedures will be based on benchmarks drawn from 
international standards and best practices. Periodic time release studies7 will be conducted to 
assess  the  impact  of  initial  reforms  and  provide  diagnostic  analysis  to  guide  further 
improvements in CIQS processes.  
 
13.  Capacity building. The TA will assist the CIQS TF in assessing skills requirements; 
developing capacity-building plans; and implement training, drills, and exercises to improve the 
capacity of local CIQS officials to implement local trade-facilitation reforms. The TA will support 
information and communication technology-related improvements and training to pave the way 
for the phased and pragmatic automation of trade transactions and services for more efficient 
and predictable transactions, better information sharing, and improved cooperation among local 
CIQS authorities.   
 
14.  Institutional strengthening. The strengthening of the CIQS TF and its secretariat will 
continue under the TA to enable them to effectively coordinate and monitor the implementation 
of the MOU and SOPs across BIMP-EAGA, as well as conduct regular consultations and policy 
dialogue between CIQS agencies and the private sector and other EAGA clusters and working 
groups. This will help identify trade-related issues and formulate solutions. The TA will support 
the establishment of in-country institutional mechanisms to help integrate border management, 
particularly at the port level.  
 
2.  Increased Private Sector Compliance with CIQS RRPs 
 
15.  Public–private  sector  partnership.  The  TA  will  support  the  BEBC’s  conduct  of 
consultations with local business communities to generate feedback on the effectiveness of 
trade facilitation programs and formulate an advocacy agenda for discussion during its annual 
dialogue with the CIQS TF and the heads of customs. This will enable the BEBC to present the 
constraints on the private sector and advocate for reforms that will support the private sector’s 
participation in cross-border trade and integration with the global supply chain.  
 
16.  Improving  compliance  with  CIQS  RRPs. The TA will address poor private sector 
compliance  with  the  CIQS  requirements.  It  will  support  regular  consultations  with  and 
familiarization workshops for local CIQS agencies, port users, and other needed to implement 
BIMP-EAGA transport facilitation arrangements to generate awareness of CIQS reforms. The 
TA will support capacity building to develop authorized economic operators at each priority entry 
point, who will benefit from fast-tracked clearance.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $1.5 million equivalent. The TA will be financed on a

importation process, from arrival of transportation vessel to removal of goods from the entry point premise.

5
grant basis from the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund8 under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for $1 million, and by the Republic of Korea e-Asia 
and Knowledge Partnership Fund9 for $500,000. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for administering and implementing the 
TA. It will collaborate with the CIQS TF, other coordinating bodies at various level, and CIQS 
agencies. When necessary, it will consult the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Centre and relevant 
BIMP-EAGA clusters and working groups. ADB will cooperate with such international technical 
organizations as the World Customs Organization, International Maritime Organization, and 
Food and Agriculture Organization, particularly in capacity building. The TA will be implemented 
over 36 months from July 2010 to June 2013. 
 
19.  The TA will finance about 59.5 person-months of consulting services, including 11.5 
person-months  of  international  consultancy  on  seven  technical  subjects:  (i)  customs,  (ii) 
immigration, (iii) animal quarantine, (iv) fisheries quarantine, (v) health quarantine, (vi) plant 
quarantine, and (vii) maritime security. An additional 48 person-months of national consultancy 
will  coordinate  with  government  agencies.  The  TA  will  tap  the  expertise  of  regional  and 
international technical organizations involved in CIQS and advertise opportunities in ADB’s 
consulting services recruitment notice for firms and/or individuals and assess the quality of 
response to define an appropriate method of selection. ADB will engage the consultants in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
Information  and  communication  technology  equipment  such  as  computers,  scanners,  fax 
machines, and hand-held radios needed in the course of implementation will be procured in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook10. Upon the completion of the project, the equipment will be transferred 
to the participating governments in accordance with the PAI 5.11.11  
 
20.  The  outputs  of  the  TA  will  be  disseminated  through  the  BIMP-EAGA  webpage 
maintained by the BIMP Facilitation Centre and ADB and at meetings of the BIMP-EAGA CIQS 
TF, heads of customs, and other clusters and working groups. The outcome of the TA will be 
reported to the annual BIMP-EAGA ministerial meeting. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea 
e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  for  Support  for  Trade  Facilitation  in  the  Brunei 
Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  International  and  national  consultants  will  be  hired  to  help  implement  technical 
assistance for Support for Trade Facilitation in the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–
Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area. An estimated 59.5 person-months of consulting services 
(11.5  person-months  of  international  consultants’  inputs  and  48  person-months  of  national 
consultants’ inputs) are required. The indicative person-month allocations and outline terms of 
reference follow. 
 
A.  Technical  Consultants  (Customs,  Immigration,  Animal  Quarantine,  Plant 
Quarantine, Fisheries Quarantine, Health Quarantine, and Security) (7 international 
consultants, 11.5 person-months combined) 
1.  Objectives and Scope of Work 
2.  One technical consultant will be recruited for each of seven sectors for 1.5 months of 
intermittent work over the project implementation period. As trade facilitation experts, they are 
expected to have extensive knowledge of and experience in trade facilitation issues, particularly 
related to areas such as transport (both maritime and land), customs, immigration, quarantine, 
and trade and port security. One person-month of consultancy will be extended to the Customs, 
Immigration,  Quarantine,  and  Security  Task  Force  (CIQS  TF)  Secretariat  to  improve 
coordination capacity across agencies. The total is 11.5 person-months. 
3.   The technical consultant shall provide policy and technical advice on the implementation 
of the Memorandum of Understanding for the Simplification, Streamlining, and Harmonization of 
Customs,  Immigration,  Quarantine,  and  Security  Procedures  in  conformity  with  relevant 
international standards and best practices. He or she is expected to validate the standard office 
procedures (SOPs) prepared by member countries and recommend practical and cost-effective 
measures  to  improve  compliance  at  entry  points,  including  institutional  strengthening  and 
capacity building. He or she will assist the CIQS TF in formulating a feasible action plan to put 
SOPs in place at priority entry points. 
2.  Requirements and Detailed Work Tasks 
4.  The experts will be responsible for the following: 
(i)  Provide technical advice on the SOPs validation and updating process. 
(ii)  Ensure that customs, immigration, quarantine, and security (CIQS) reforms and 
trade facilitation measures are efficient and practical under the current situation 
and that capability at each entry point complies with international standards. 
(iii)  Assist the CIQS TF in formulating a feasible plan of action for each entry point 
and review the progress of reform implementation to ensure the technical quality 
of outcomes. 
(iv)  Participate as resource persons and provide technical inputs during CIQS TF 
meetings as required. 
(v)  Prepare reports on duties performed.

B.  Project Administration Consultants (2 national, 48 person-months combined) 
1.  Objectives and Scope of Work 
5.  Two  national  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  coordinate  the  implementation  of  the 
technical assistance with government agencies and Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–
Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area bodies. They should have good understanding of and 
experience with national systems and processes in member countries and the institutional 
mechanisms of the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth 
Area. They should possess good understanding of and working experience in trade facilitation. 
They should be familiar with project administration under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
support the work of international consultants and resource persons. 
2.  Requirements and Detailed Work Tasks 
6.  The national consultants should undertake the following: 
(i)  Organize  and  coordinate  with  related  agencies,  including  ADB,  member 
countries, partner organizations, and international consultants regarding project 
activities,  ensure  timeliness,  and  make  a  preliminary  assessment  of  project 
deliverables.  
(ii)  Coordinate and prepare reports and updates of project progress (i.e., inception, 
midterm, and final reports, and various sector reports as needed) to be submitted 
to ADB and the CIQS TF.  
(iii)  Assist the CIQS TF and international consultants in conducting consultations and 
dialogues with local governments and local private firms on transport and trade 
facilitation  and  encourage  their  active  and  effective  support  to  identify  and 
implement  CIQS  measures  to  enhance  the  movement  of  people  and  goods 
across borders. 
(iv)  Liaise with CIQS agencies on their activities; assist international consultants with 
field visits, including arranging meetings with agencies and stakeholders; assist 
consultants in organizing training, workshops, and conferences; and serve as 
resource persons for meetings, training, and conferences, where appropriate. 
(v)  Support  the  processing  of  procedures  for  project  implementation  and 
management. 
(vi)  Participate in project-related missions, as needed.
